Abstract#1: Producer, International Astronomical Union, Air Force Cambridge Research Laboratory, National Science Foundation. Working committee members, HJ Smith, MN Gnevyshev, RV Giovanelli, J Rosch. Director, HJ Smith. Production, JT Loomis, WD Booton, CJ Hume. Film depicts sun activity from 11 observatory stations around the world with date, station, and time noted in each shot.
Note#1: 00:00:00 Title card reads, “A Continuous Solar Movie – 6-20 July 1959” “Produced for the International Astronomical Union – By the working committee: HJ Smith, MN Gnevyshev, RV Giovanelli, J Rosch. With the support of Air Force Cambridge Research Laboratory & National Science Foundation -- Direction, HJ Smith. Production, JT Loomis, WD Booton, CJ Hume,” “Contributing Observatories: Abastrumani, Climax – High Alt. Obs. – Capetown, Dublin – Greenwich – Lockheed – McMath, Hulbert – Meudon – Mitaka – Sacramento Peak – Sydney, C.S.I.R.O. – Tashkent”; 00:00:51 The screen changes to depict a circle with the four cardinal directions (North, South, East, & West). The screen also reads in the top left and right corners, “Date, Station -- Universal Time”; 00:00:59 A view of the sun’s activity is shown through a telescope. The duration of the film shows views of the sun from different observatories while recording the date, station, and time; 00:14:50 End credits read, “THE END – Produced at Sacramento Peak”

Abstract#1: Notes from container, "Hi-quality prom. [prominence] films." Reel contains images of the sun's corona, with solar explosions, dated between June 28, 1945 and March 27, 1946. Shot at 0.1 fps. Includes title cards with original research notes.
Note#1: 00:00:00 Film begins by showing footage of solar prominence. The entire film depicts different views of solar flares and explosions.

Title#1: Explosions on the sun, print from master
Abstract#1: Notes from container: "Poor quality 1970 print of old master." Reel contains images of the sun's corona, with solar explosions, dated between June 28, 1945 and March 27, 1946. Shot at 0.1 fps. Includes informational intertitltes for a more general public.
Note#1: 00:00:00 Title card reads "EXPLOSIONS ON THE SUN," "Solar Prominences Photographed through a special narrow-band filter in red light of hydrogen. A metal disc eclipses the sun."; 00:00:16 A view of the sun, showing solar flares; 00:00:26 A man works with a device or machine. The screen then reads, "These pictures cover an area 50,000 miles wide by 400,000 miles high. The earth, to the same scale would be the size of this dot: ·"; 00:00:28 Screen shows the sun again. Another screen reads, "Active region with explosive surge -- January 4, 1945 -- Acceleration: 400 times." The screen changes to show the solar explosions again; 00:01:12 The screen reads, "Graceful fountain -- December 19, 1945 -- Acceleration: 400 times"; 00:01:29 Screen reads, "This prominence develops into an eruptive arch -- Exposure interrupted by clouds -- June 28, 1945 -- Acceleration: 400 times"; 00:02:21 Screen reads, "Matter streaming downward in loops -- January 28, 1946 -- Acceleration: 600 at beginning -- 1200 at end"; 00:02:35 Screen reads, "Note formation of dazzling flare"; 00:02:54 Screen reads, "Inverted cone prominence. Also note pulsing surges -- November 22, 1945 -- Acceleration: 600 times" Screen shows solar flares again; 00:03:25 Screen reads, "An eruptive arch -- the largest ever photographed -- June 4, 1946 -- Acceleration: 600 times"; 00:03:35 Screen reads, "A REPETITION -- Expanding at the rate of nearly 100 miles per second, the arch probably became almost as large as the sun itself."; 00:04:05 Screen reads, "LOOP PROMINENCES -- The marked curvature may result from magnetic fields of nearby sun-spots. -- March 10, 1946 -- Acceleration: 400 times"; 00:04:29 Screen reads, "MORE LOOPS -- Note how matter becomes luminous at high levels -- March 27, 1946 -- Acceleration: 600 times"; 00:05:11 Screen reads, "Active region. Watch sharply for eruptive surge returning sunward along original path -- March 29, 1946 -- Acceleration: 1200 times"; 00:05:33 Screen reads, "Suspended cloud -- March 23, 1946 -- Acceleration: 600 times"; 00:06:03 Screen reads, "SERIES OF SURGES -- The largest reaches altitude of 250,000 miles -- June 12, 1946 -- Acceleration: 600 times" -- 00:06:45 Screen reads, "Giant replica of atomic bomb explosion -- even to the mushroom cap -- February 14, 1946 -- Acceleration: 1200 times"; 00:07:00 Screen reads, "A massive prominence of great brilliance -- February 27, 1946 -- Acceleration: 600 times"; 00:07:16 Screen reads, "Formation of loops with very pronounced downward streaming -- February 24, 1946 -- Acceleration: 600 times"; 00:07:51 Screen reads, "THE END" and film ends.
Physical Location#1: University of Colorado Boulder Libraries Rare and Distinctive Collections

Abstract#1: Producer, Tetsuya T. Fujita, University of Chicago, NASA, ESSA. Title from film container. Label on film reads, "Application of ATS-enhanced photos for hurricane research, University of Chicago." Title on screen, "SMRP Film 009." Container notes indicate that reel is "missing 2 scenes." Reel contains images of hurricanes with and without geographic coordinates, including Hurricane Debby (August 1969) and Hurricane Camille (1969), filmed "from enhanced ATS photos" and "from regular ATS photos." Film presented at the Sixth Hurricane Conference, 4 December 1969, Miami.
Note#1: 00:00:00 Title card reads, “Application of Enhanced ATS Pictures for Hurricane Research,” “by Tetsuya T. Fujita – presented at the Sixth Hurricane Conference – 4 December 1969 -- Miami”; 00:00:07 Screen reads, “Hurricane Camille Aug. 1969,” “Filmed from: Regular ATS Photos.” The screen changes to show an aerial view of a hurricane; 00:00:47 Screen reads, “Filmed from: Regular ATS Photos” and continues to show an aerial view of a weather system; 00:01:21 Screen reads, “Enhanced and rectified Camille – 17 August 1969.” An aerial view of hurricane Camille is depicted; 00:01:44 Screen reads, “Experimental enhancement of Hurricane Debby -- 20 August. 1969” and an aerial view of hurricane Debby is depicted; 00:02:06 End credits read, “SMRP Film 009 – T.T. Fujita – The University of Chicago – November 1969 – Sponsored by NASA and ESSA”

Abstract#1: Reel contains collection of clips. Container label reads, "General Circulation Model, with Titles." Begins with credits, noting producer, National Center For Atmospheric Research, Boulder, Colorado (University Corporation for Atmospheric Research, under contract with the National Science Foundation). Title on screen, "General Circulation Model, Two-Level Version, January." U3435." Contains graphic of a rotating globe with dates of measurement and note on surface pressure countour. Also includes text of quotation, "Text of quotation: "'Perhaps someday in the dim future it will be possible to advance the computations faster than the weather advances and at a cost less than the saving to mankind due to the information gained. But that is a dream.' - L. F. Richardson, Weather Prediction by Numberical Process, 1922." Reel ends with additional globe graphic footage, labeled "Washington global model, with clouds."
Note#1: 00:00:01 Title card reads, “Produced by NCAR – The National Center for Atmospheric Research – Boulder, Colorado.” “NCAR is operated by The University Corporation for Atmospheric Research under contract with the National Science Foundation.” “General circulation model – two level version – January.” “Surface pressure contour interval = 5 mb.”; 00:00:34 An image of earth appears on a red background and slowly rotates. High and low systems are represented on the globe; 00:02:21 Screen reads, “’Perhaps [some day] in the dim future it will be possible to advance the computations faster than the weather advances and at a cost less than the saving to mankind due to the information gained. But that is a dream.’ – L. F. Richardson – weather prediction by numerical process, 1922.” 00:02:39 An image of earth appears on a red background again and displays high and low weather systems.

Title#1: High speed photographs of water droplets
Abstract#1: Experiments conducted by Wendell A. Mordy. Description from film: "These experiments are designed to study the role of surface, electrical charge, and aerodynamic forces on droplet coalescence." Images show water droplets on a backlit grid. Film container reads, "Property of U. of Nevada Desert Research Institute., W.A. Palmer Films, Inc. San Francisco."
Note#1: 00:00:08 Title card reads “High Speed Photographs of Water Droplets,” “Experiments conducted by Wendell A. Mordy.” “These experiments are designed to study the role of surface, electrical charge, and aerodynamic forces on droplet coalescence”; 00:01:06 Scene changes to show graph paper and an instrument on the top right corner of the screen; 00:01:41 Water droplets quickly fall from the top right corner; 00:04:16 Scene changes to show water drops falling from the top left corner of the screen, they appear to be larger droplets; 00:09:46 The background changes to a white background and the water drops fall from the top center portion of the screen. They also move in a crisscross pattern.

Name#1: United States. National Aeronautics and Space Administration
Abstract#1: Producer, NASA, ESSA. Principle experimenters, Verner W. Suomi (University of Washington), Tetsuya T. Fujita (University of Chicago), Robert H. Simpson (National Hurricane Center), R. Cecil Gentry (NHRL). Chief of satellite operator, Vincent J. Oliver (NESC). Reel contains a series of satellite images of hurricanes.
Note#1: 00:00:00 Film begins with a satellite image of a hurricane; 00:00:13 Screen reads, “1968 Hurricane Watch Experiment -- Conducted jointly by NASA and ESSA – Principal experimenters – Verner E. Suomi, Prof. University of Wisconsin – Tetsuya T. Fujita, Prof. University of Chicago – Vincent J. Oliver, Chief Satellite Applications, NESC – Robert H. Simpson, Director National Hurricane Center – R. Cecil Gentry, Director NHRL”; 00:00:31 Screen reads, “Hurricane Abby -- June 3-6, 1968” “Daily view on ESSA Mosaic – June 1-9, 1968” The screen changes to show satellite images of a hurricane around the Gulf of Mexico; 00:00:51 Screen reads, “June 3, 1968 – Global view” the screen changes to show a global view of clouds and weather systems; 00:01:34 Screen reads, “Local view” and shows a close-up of the Gulf of Mexico; 00:03:01 Screen reads, “Local view” and shows the close-up of a hurricane; 00:03:54 Screen reads, “June 5, 1968 – Global View” and shows the cloud system around the world. The screen slowly zooms in towards South America; 00:04:42 Screen reads, “Local view” and shows a hurricane around the Gulf of Mexico; 00:05:37 Screen reads, “June 6, 1968 – Global view” and shows the weather systems around the globe. The screen slowly zooms in on South America; 00:06:23 Screen reads, “Local view” and shows a hurricane around the Gulf of Mexico; 00:07:25 Screen reads, “Hurricane Brenda – June 21, 1968” The screen changes to show and aerial view of Hurricane Brenda; 00:08:27 Screen reads, “Hurricane Candy – Formative Stage – June 22, 1968”; 00:09:20 Screen reads, “June 23, 1968” and continues to show Hurricane Candy; 00:10:03 End credits read, “We wish to acknowledge direct contributions of: Robert J. Darcey, Chief ATS Office, NASA – Don V. Fordyce, ATS Project Manager, NASA – John W. Lindstrom, ATS Data Utilization Manager, NASA – Ralph K. Anderson, Satellite Applications, NESC – Lester F. Hubert, Chief Synoptic Meteorology Branch, NESC – Linwood F. Whitney Jr., Synoptic Meteorology Branch, NESC – This film was produced at SMRP Department of Geophysical Sciences – The University of Chicago.” The final image zooms away from the aerial view of the same hurricane shown at the beginning of the film.

Title#1: NCAR balloon facility, Palestine/Flight of U. of Arizona polarimeter
Abstract#1: Notes from container include, "May 1965 (Ewy, Ruttenberg, Gray)." Reel contains images of the NCAR weather balloon facility, including aerial views of farmland, interior and exterior shots of the facility, aerial maps, images of equipment and researchers. Scenes also include workers unloading and assembling outdoor equipment, launching of an instrument into the sky.
Note#1: 00:00:00 Film begins by showing an aerial view of farmland and the NCAR facility; 00:00:54 Exterior view of the NCAR weather balloon facility; 00:01:08 A white man works on a metal structure inside the facility. Close-up views of other machines and equipment shown; 00:01:40 Several unidentified white men are working in the facility. One man writes on a map around Texas; 00:03:03 A large, yellow vehicle is operated outside of the facility. There are words written on the side of the vehicle that read, “Tiny Tim”; 00:04:48 The men continue to work outside with other vehicles and equipment. They lay down a long, red piece of plastic on the ground and tape various pieces of equipment to it; 00:06:12 A weather balloon is attached and inflated from the red stretch of plastic; 00:07:10 The balloon is released into the air. The film shows an apparatus hanging from the bottom of the balloon as it travels; 00:08:27 Another white man stands at a control station, possibly collecting or recording data; 00:09:25 Two white men are shown piloting, possibly the weather balloon. Aerial views of the ground are shown again.

Title#1: The wind-driven circulation of the North Pacific
Abstract#1: Producer, James O'Brien, National Center for Atmospheric Research, Boulder Colorado (University Corporation for Atmospheric Research, under contract with the National Science Foundation). Reel contains graphics of the Pacific Ocean and the globe with informational intertitles, including "mean zonal stress for the Northern Hemisphere, from Hellerman, 1967," "mass-transport stream function in time starting from a barotropic ocean at rest," and "particle trajectories of using the vertically-integrated velocity field at 200 days."
Note#1: 00:00:14 Title card reads, “The Wind-Driven Circulation of the North Pacific Ocean – By James J. O’Brien,” “Produced by NCAR – The National Center for Atmospheric Research – Boulder, Colorado – September, 1968,” “NCAR is operated by The University Corporation for Atmospheric Research under contract with the National Science Foundation”; 00:00:25 Screen reads, “Case 1 – The stress function of the mean zonal stress for the northern hemisphere from Hellerman, 1967, I.E. The Stress is independent of Longitude.” The screen changes to depict a graph or chart with the title “Annual Mean Zonal Wind Stress Northern Hemisphere”; 00:00:41 Screen reads, “Depth of ocean 10+5 – Horizontal exchange coef. (cm2/sec) 10+8 – Grid spacing (∆ꭅ=∆0) (degrees) 1.25”; 00:00:44 “The next two sequences show the mass-transport stream function in time starting from a barotropic ocean at rest.” A graphic of earth appears on the screen.; 00:02:18 Screen reads, “The western layer” and continues to show a close-up of the globe; 00:03:45 Screen reads, “The following sequence depicts several particle trajectories using the vertically integrated velocity field at 200 days.” The graphic of earth appears again; 00:04:34 Screen reads, “Case 2 – The stress function is the annual mean – Stress for the northern pacific from Hellerman, 1967, and is dependent on latitude and longitude.” A graphic of the globe appears with a title that reads, “Annual mean of eastward-directed wind stress (DYNES/CM2)”; 00:04:55 Screen again reads, “Depth of ocean 10+5 – Horizontal exchange coef. (cm2/sec) 10+8 – Grid spacing (∆ꭅ=∆0) (degrees) 1.25,” “The next two sequences show the mass-transport stream function in time starting from a barotropic ocean at rest.” A depiction of the earth is shown again; 00:06:33 Screen reads, “The western boundary layer” and shows a close-up of the globe; 00:08:04 Screen reads, “The following screen depicts several particle trajectories using the vertically-integrated velocity field at 200 days.” A view of earth appears on the screen; 00:08:52 End credits read, “The End.”

Abstract#1: Reel contains footage of a research team in the snow in a mountain landscape. They assemble equipment, including a red balloon and a yellow piece of machinery on wheels, pulled through the snow by a large truck. A series of balloons is released, then retrieved by the team.
Note#1: 00:00:00 Film begins by showing a group of men working with equipment to set up a weather balloon. The camera pans across the mountain range; 00:05:48 A vehicle travels along the snow to inflate a clear weather balloon; 00:07:42 The weather balloon is taken down; 00:08:29 The vehicle travels along the snow again and they deploy the weather balloon; 00:09:04 The weather balloon is taken down again and the film ends.
